facts.text: For the period August 16, 1950 to March 31, 1951 the respondents were assessed to sales-tax under the Travancore Cochin General Sales-tax Act, 1950, by the assessing authority, Moovattupuzha, on a turnover of Rs. 14,04,732/716 which included Rs. 49,318/7/4 collected by the respondents from their constituents as tax on their sale transactions.
The respondents paid the tax assessed.
The respondents commenced an action in the Court of the District Judge, Parur, for a decree for Rs. 7,577/9/1 claiming that the amount was in excess of tax lawfully due from them under the Act.
The Court of First Instance decreed the claim for Rs. 7,477/9/1 with interest and proportionate costs.
The High Court of Kerala confirmed that decree in A.S. No. 190 of 1959 on October 7, 1963.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court by the State of Kerala.
Section 23-A incorporated in the Travancore-Cochin General Sales-tax Act by Act 18 of 1955 after the suit was instituted by the respondents.
Notification No. SRI-1643-51-RD dated March 31, 1951 added clause (l) to r. 7 of the Rules: 'all amounts of sales-tax collected by the dealer' effective from April 1, 1951.

legal_issues.text: Whether the jurisdiction of the Civil Court to try the suit is excluded.
Whether amounts of sales-tax collected by the dealer are includible in the taxable turnover for the period ending March 31, 1951.

petitioner_arguments.text: Jurisdiction of the civil court is excluded by necessary implication from the scheme of the Travancore-Cochin General Sales-tax Act which sets up a complete code for levy, assessment, collection and refund of tax.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Scheme of Travancore-Cochin General Sales-tax Act, 1950 (ss. 3, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 24); Raleigh Investment Company Ltd. v. Governor-General in Council; K.S. Venkatraman & Co. (P) Ltd. v. State of Madras; Kamala Mills Ltd. v. State of Bombay

respondent_arguments.text: In the absence of an express provision in the Act excluding the jurisdiction of the civil court, the suit was maintainable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Provincial Government of Madras v. J.S. Basappa; No s. 23-A at time of suit

respondent_arguments.text: The Sales-tax Officer acted in defiance of mandatory provisions by including sales tax collected in turnover, as per r. 7 and definition of turnover in s. 2(k).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Travancore-Cochin General Sales-tax Act, s. 2(k); r. 7 of Rules

court_reasoning.text: S. 23-A does not apply as it was enacted after the suit; however, jurisdiction excluded by clear implication from the scheme of the Act which constitutes a complete machinery for assessment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The Act sets up a tribunal competent to decide all questions of fact and law; liability arises under the Act and must be determined thereunder.

court_reasoning.text: Basappa's case wrongly decided; distinguished from Kamala Mills where jurisdiction excluded even for outside sales due to complete machinery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jurisdiction may be excluded expressly or by necessary implication; Basappa overruled implicitly.

court_reasoning.text: No violation of mandatory provisions; sales tax collected includible in turnover under s. 2(k) as aggregate amount for which goods sold; amendment to r.7(l) not clarificatory but additional from Apr 1, 1951.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Turnover includes tax as part of price; no provision excludes it pre-amendment.

holdings.text: Jurisdiction of civil court excluded by necessary implication from the scheme of the Travancore-Cochin General Sales-tax Act.
Sales tax collected by dealer includible in taxable turnover for period ending March 31, 1951.

precedents_cited.case_name: Provincial Government of Madras (Now Andhra Pradesh) v. J.S. Basappa
precedents_cited.relevance: Held civil suit maintainable absent express exclusion; court holds wrongly decided.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raleigh Investment Company Ltd. v. Governor-General in Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Scheme of Income-tax Act excludes civil jurisdiction by implication.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.S. Venkatraman & Co. (P) Ltd. v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Statute creating liability and machinery bars civil suit by implication.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kamala Mills Ltd. v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Civil jurisdiction excluded expressly and by implication for sales tax refunds even on non-taxable sales.

precedents_cited.case_name: George Oakes Pvt. Ltd. v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Turnover includes sales tax collected as part of aggregate sale price.

precedents_cited.case_name: Firm of Illuri Subbayya Chetty & Sons
Secretary of State for India v. Mask & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Civil courts can examine non-compliance with statute or judicial procedure.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore-Cochin General Sales-tax Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Complete machinery for assessment excludes civil jurisdiction; defines turnover to include sales tax collected.

statutes_cited.name: Rules under Travancore-Cochin General Sales-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Exemptions in computation of net turnover; clause (l) effective from 1951-04-01 excludes sales tax collected prospectively.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Ban on taxing outside sales; referenced in Kamala Mills.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Express bar on questioning assessment in civil court.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales-tax Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Referenced in Basappa and Kamala Mills for exclusion of jurisdiction.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, holding that the jurisdiction of the civil court was excluded by necessary implication under the scheme of the Travancore-Cochin General Sales-tax Act, and that sales tax collected was includible in turnover; decrees of lower courts set aside.

key_quotes.text: "No suit or other civil proceeding shall, except as expressly provided in this Act, be instituted in any court to set aside or modify any assessment made under this Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of s. 23-A, but held inapplicable retrospectively.

key_quotes.text: the jurisdiction of the civil court may be excluded expressly or by clear implication arising from the scheme of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle applied to exclude jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: If a statute imposes a liability and creates an effective machinery for deciding questions of law or fact arising in regard to that liability, it may, by necessary implication, bar the maintainability of a civil suit.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Under the definition of turnover the aggregate amount for which goods are bought or sold is taxable. This aggregate amount includes the tax as part of the price paid by the buyer.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From George Oakes, holds tax includible in turnover.
